name: (2E)-3-[5-(4-Methylphenyl)-2-furyl]-1-phenylprop-2-en-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1191

name: (2E)-3-[5-(4-Methylphenyl)-2-furyl]-1-phenylprop-2-en-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1191
Reason: The compound in question can be broken down into three parts for analysis: a phenyl ring (Ph), a 4-methylphenyl group (p-tolyl), and a furan ring with an additional phenyl substituent. The basic phenyl ring has a known melting point of around 41°C. The p-tolyl group is expected to increase the melting point due to increasing the molecular weight and providing some additional van der Waals interactions; we can approximate this increase at about 20°C. The furan ring with an extra phenyl is likely to increase the melting point significantly owing to the rigidity and planarity it introduces to the molecule, as well as potential π-π stacking interactions. This effect might be even stronger than the p-tolyl group, so an increase of approximately 30°C can be predicted. Additionally, the conjugated system across the molecule provides further rigidity, which should also increase the melting point roughly by an additional 10°C. All these increments are based on general trends observed for similar functional groups in other molecules.
